image.altText: A mug shot of Peter Rex Dansie.

props.synopsis: Notorious killer Peter Dansie dies at the age of 75, seven years after his act of "ultimate evil", in which he murdered his wife Helen by pushing her wheelchair into a pond in Adelaide's parklands.

title.children: 'Evil and despicable' wife-killer Peter Dansie dies in custody seven years after Adelaide pond murder

image.altText: A woman smiles in front of the Sydney Harbor Bridge.

props.synopsis: Clifford Neumann admits to killing mother-of-five Victoria Ann Stewart whose death was one of several which prompted South Australia's upcoming royal commission into family and domestic violence.

title.children: Man pleads guilty to murder of Adelaide mother-of-five Victoria Stewart

image.altText: a man in a business suit walks outside a court building

props.synopsis: Italian tourist Gabriele Cairo pleads guilty to causing the deaths of South Australian couple Cynthia and John Clark, and their daughter Jacquie, in a crash at a regional intersection in October.

title.children: Tourist pleads guilty over SA intersection crash that killed three members from same family

image.altText: Restaurant owner Deanna Flynn Wallis inside the tavern in Mount Barker.

props.synopsis: For many years, Deanna knew there was something about her that was "different". Now, she's taking part in a rollout of "quiet dinners" for people with sensory needs around food.

title.children: Adelaide Hills restaurant offers 'quiet dinners' and sensory-friendly menu for autistic community

image.altText: A large group of people gathers for a rally one sign says girls just want to feel safe

props.synopsis: The latest monthly crime statistics released by SA Police show 22 murders were reported across the state in the past year – a 69 per cent increase from the 13 murders reported in the year prior.

title.children: Crime statistics reveal murders, shoplifting on the rise in South Australia

image.altText: Cars line a highway

props.synopsis: NSW Police confirm a man has died after a head-on collision outside of Broken Hill, closing a section of the Barrier Highway.

title.children: Man killed in head-on collision east of Broken Hill on Barrier Highway

image.altText: Whyalla steelworks owner Sanjeev Gupta

props.synopsis: GFG Alliance boss Sanjeev Gupta says the blast furnace — which has been offline since mid-March — has been restarted, and steelmaking should begin again next month.

title.children: 'Concrete progress': Whyalla steelworks blast furnace restarted

image.altText: A young blonde woman named Ariel Bombara sitting while being interviewed.

props.synopsis: The daughter of Mark James Bombara, who shot and killed Jennifer and Gretl Petelczyc in their Floreat home, says police were warned about her father's disturbing behaviour.

title.children: Daughter of Perth killer warned police three times he was an 'imminent threat'

image.altText: A man lays against the wall of a car park.

props.synopsis: Welcome to Portland, Oregon, the US city that decriminalised drugs and nearly immediately regretted it.

title.children: This progressive US state pioneered a radical drug policy, then overdose deaths skyrocketed

image.altText: a young girl smiling and holding an umbrella

props.synopsis: Kallista Mutten was questioned about her methamphetamine use during the six-week trial into the death of the nine-year-old in early 2022.

title.children: Charlise Mutten's mother breaks down in court after being accused of fatally shooting 9yo

image.altText: Close-up of tail of a Virgin Australia aircraft at Brisbane Airport.

props.synopsis: Federal police arrest a man who allegedly ran naked down the aisle of a Virgin plane on a flight from Perth to Melbourne, knocking a crew member to the floor and forcing the aircraft to turn around.

title.children: Passenger arrested after allegedly running naked through Virgin plane, knocking over crew member

image.altText: Surrounded by shadows, Jordon Steele-John sits in the chamber.

props.synopsis: A staff member in Parliament House has had a seizure after the Department of Parliamentary Services denied requests to adjust lighting in their office.

title.children: Parliament staffer has seizure after request for lighting change not acted on

image.altText: James Marape salutes as he walks past defence personnel outside parliament house.

props.synopsis: As one of Papua New Guinea's remote villages grapples with one of the worst natural disasters in its history, the prime minister is busy attending to his own political crisis.

title.children: A king and a US president sent their condolences to PNG. But where is the nation's own prime minister?

image.altText: Digging with hands

props.synopsis: The Papua New Guinea government says more than 2,000 people are believed to have been buried alive in a landslide. But the remains of only six people have been recovered so far.

title.children: 'A situation that is getting worse': Why only six bodies of the thousands feared dead in PNG have been recovered

image.altText: A blonde woman with shoulder length hair speaking with two other women behind her on either side

props.synopsis: The eSafety commissioner's fight against X over videos of the Wakeley stabbing just got messier, with two new groups from the other side of the world granted leave to join the case.

title.children: Something very weird just happened in the eSafety vs X case

image.altText: Jane Hume at senate estimates

props.synopsis: Senators have spent the day debating transparency and "vexatious" questioning at estimates hearings.

title.children: Government handbook instructing bureaucrats to be 'vague' not useful, public servant tells Senate estimates

image.altText: A wide shot of iron ore being loaded onto a ship in Port Hedland.

props.synopsis: Economists are predicting the price of Australia's most valuable export, iron ore, to remain much higher than government forecasts, meaning there could be a lot more money to spend in the next federal budget.

title.children: New 'super bull' commodities phase could dramatically change budget outlook

image.altText: Rolfe 2

props.synopsis: Former NT police officer Zachary Rolfe says he is "ready to move on" during questioning at the coronial inquest into the police shooting of Kumanjayi Walker, but says he feels "very badly" for Mr Walker's family.

title.children: Zachary Rolfe 'bored' of Kumanjayi Walker inquest, coroner hears

image.altText: A woman wearing glasses looks right at the camera.

props.synopsis: Justine and her partner cut their losses and sold their home cheap in the inner suburb of Darwin after months of no takers.

title.children: 'There were no takers at all': Seller loses $100,000 putting home on the market in Darwin

image.altText: Rob Stefanic holds his hands together while giving evidence at senate estimates

props.synopsis: The head of the federal government department tasked with overseeing Parliament House has flatly denied he was in a relationship with his deputy while he was her boss. But he has refused to tell Senate estimates if the two had a relationship before or after working together.

title.children: Parliament House boss denies relationship with deputy when her boss, won't confirm other times

image.altText: Nestory Irankunda pictured representing Australia

props.synopsis: Eighteen-year-old Bayern Munich-bound sensation Nestory Irankunda looks set to be locked down by Football Australia with a Socceroos call-up next month.

title.children: Teen sensation to be named in Socceroos squad just days after flagging he could switch allegiances if he misses out

image.altText: A wide shot of Rafael Nadal waving to the French Open crowd as fans applaud him as he leaves the Roland Garros court.

props.synopsis: As he has done in every match he played, Rafael Nadal refuses to accept that his career is over until it's over, but his legacy as one of the greatest of all time is secure no matter how it ends.

title.children: 'The King is dead, long live the King': Why Rafael Nadal leaves a legacy that will never be touched

image.altText: Josh Wilson sits in question time at parliament house

props.synopsis: A Labor backbencher has called on Israel to end its assault on Rafah. Follow live.

title.children: Israel's Rafah actions 'can't be described as self-defence', says Labor MP

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Labor backbencher says Israeli strike on Rafah 'can't be described as self-defence'
Giles distances government from visa reinstatement
PM pays tribute to victims of PNG landslide

image.altText: Police tape in front of a river and a bridge in the distance / police looking over the edge of a bridge with a river below

props.synopsis: Police hold concerns for the wellbeing of a newborn baby and its mother after a passer-by found "signs of birth" on a riverbank in suburban Sydney.

title.children: Woman urged to visit hospital after 'placenta and umbilical cord' found on Sydney riverbank

image.altText: a large stone and steel sign at the entrance to uq that says 'the university of queensland australia st lucia campus'

props.synopsis: The university has sent an email to staff apologising for the mistake, which it said spanned from January 2017 to December 2023.

title.children: University of Queensland underpaid casual workers by nearly $8 million over seven years

image.altText: A silver box with an intricate etching.

props.synopsis: Few people have ever heard Wu-Tang Clan's legendary seventh studio album. That's because only a single copy was ever made and the masters were destroyed. But visitors to the Mona gallery in Hobart will get a chance.

title.children: It's the most expensive album in history and few people in the world have heard it. Now, it's coming to Tassie

image.altText: A smiling brown-haired woman puts a 'sold' sticker on a 'for auction' sign outside a house.

props.synopsis: A surge in home loan hardship requests and a record number of quick resales are two signs that Australia is still perilously close to the edge of the mortgage cliff.

title.children: Behind the smiles and sold stickers, there are early signs of illness in Australia's property market

image.altText: A woman wearing blue gloves pots a basil plant in a terracotta pot.

props.synopsis: Fungal infections such as mucormycosis can be life-threatening but they're also very rare. Nevertheless, there may be some precautions worth taking.

title.children: What to wear to protect yourself from fungal infections while gardening

image.altText: A patron a concert holds a shard of glass up to a protester at the front of a concert.

props.synopsis: Tensions flare at a Hobart concert after pro-Palestinian protesters disrupted the performance of Jewish singer-songwriter Deborah Conway, with one audience member smashing a wine glass on the stage and holding the shattered stem towards the face of an activist.

title.children: Deborah Conway concert flares as patron threatens pro-Palestinian protester with broken wine glass

image.altText: australian mps hold their thumbs up at an event celebrating the inauguration of Taiwan's new president

props.synopsis: Politicians have spoken out against a direct email from the Chinese Consulate-General in Sydney which raised concerns about 11 MPs attending a Taiwanese function.

title.children: MPs push back against 'intimidation' from Chinese consulate-general over attendance at Taiwan celebration

image.altText: A family photo featuring mum, dad, and five kids, posing in front of a scenic rainforest and body of water.

props.synopsis: Queensland's Daintree Rainforest does not have mains electricity — so many residents are burning hundreds of litres of "dirty" diesel fuel a week just to keep their businesses running.

title.children: Burning hundreds of litres of diesel just to stay open: Welcome to the rainforest without electricity

image.altText: Close-up of a bomb being carried under a fighter jet taking off.

props.synopsis: Russia's big, cheap, retrofitted Soviet-era bombs have become one of its most effective weapons in its full-scale invasion of Ukraine. Locals who have seen their devastating effects view them as a "super weapon".

title.children: Why Ukraine's hands are tied to stop Russia gaining ground with its new main weapon

image.altText: A man is led away from a home by police.

props.synopsis: The breach emerged during a bail application for 69-year-old Steve Fabriczy, who is accused of killing Canberra grandmother Irma Palasics in 1999 during a violent home invasion.

title.children: Canberra's jail found to be breaching human rights of man accused of killing Irma Palasics

image.altText: A blurred figure walks past a Country Road storefront, with mannequins in the window.

props.synopsis: One of Australia's biggest and most successful fashion chains is being hit with sexual harassment allegations. Follow the day's events and insights as they happen with our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Country Road reponds to sexual harassment allegations, while ASX flatlines with UK and US markets closed

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Australian Community Media offers assets to Southern Cross Media Group
We expect insolvencies in the retail sector to increase, says CreditorWatch chief economist

image.altText: A woman standing on an oval smiles. Two women stand near here.

props.synopsis: New courses to help people rejoin the workforce after years of unemployment are teaching skills in fitness, nutrition, money management and self-esteem.

title.children: How does getting fit help you land a job? These women are finding out
